This is a [[congenital disorder|congenital disease]] most commonly found in small breeds such as the [[Brussels Griffon]] and the [[Cavalier King Charles Spaniel]]. Other breeds known to be affected include the [[Bichon Frise]], [[Boston terrier]], [[bull terrier]], [[Chihuahua (dog)|Chihuahua]], [[French bulldog]], [[Havanese dog|Havanese]], [[King Charles spaniel]] (the English toy spaniel), [[Maltese dog|Maltese]], miniature dachshunds, miniature and toy poodles, [[Papillon dog|Papillon]], [[Pomeranian (dog)|Pomeranian]], [[Pugs]], [[Shih Tzu]], [[Staffordshire bull terrier]], and the [[Yorkshire terrier]]. Signs may include [[ataxia]], weakness, and neck pain.<ref>{{cite web | title = Spinal Cord Disorders: Small Animals| work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/100416.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-19 }}</ref> *[[Epilepsy in dogs]] can be a primary, [[idiopathic]], inherited disorder or secondary to previous head trauma or CNS infections. Idiopathic epilepsy is commonly found in breeds such as [[German Shepherd Dog]]s, [[Beagle]]s, and [[Dachshund]]s. The most common sign recurring generalized [[seizure]]s beginning at a young adult age.<ref name=Chrisman_2003>{{cite book|author1=Chrisman, Cheryl |author2=Clemmons, Roger |author3=Mariani, Christopher |author4=Platt, Simon |title=Neurology for the Small Animal Practitioner|edition=1st|publisher=Teton New Media|year=2003|isbn=1-893441-82-2}}</ref> *[[Cerebellar hypoplasia (non-human)|Cerebellar hypoplasia]] is an incomplete development of the [[cerebellum]]. The most common cause in dogs is an [[in utero]] infection with [[canine herpesvirus]].<ref name=Chrisman_2003/> It is also seen associated with [[lissencephaly]] in [[Fox Terrier (Wire)|Wire-haired Fox Terrier]]s and [[Irish Setter]]s, and as a separate condition in [[Chow Chow]]s.<ref>{{cite web | title = Cerebellar Disorders: Small Animals| work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/100413.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-19 }}</ref> *[[Polyneuropathy in dogs and cats|Polyneuropathy]] is a collection of peripheral nerve disorders that often are breed-related in dogs. Polyneuropathy indicates that multiple nerves are involved, unlike [[mononeuropathy]]. Polyneuropathy usually involves motor nerve dysfunction, also known as lower motor neuron disease. *[[Canine cognitive dysfunction]] is a progressive disease occurring in older dogs, which is similar to the dementia which occurs in humans with [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schütt|first1=T|last2=Toft|first2=N|last3=Berendt|first3=M|title=Cognitive function, progression of age-related behavioral changes, biomarkers, and survival in dogs more than 8 years old|journal=Journal of Veterinary Internal Medicine|date=2015|volume=29|issue=6|pages=1569–77|pmid=26463980|pmc=4895687|doi=10.1111/jvim.13633}}</ref> *[[Scotty Cramp]] is a disease in [[Scottish Terrier]]s causing spasms and hyperflexion and hyperextension of the legs. It is caused by a disorder in [[serotonin]] metabolism that causes a deficiency of available serotonin.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Cauda equina syndrome]]*, also known as degenerative lumbosacral stenosis, in dogs is a compression of the [[cauda equina]] by a narrowing of the lumbosacral [[vertebral canal]]. It is most commonly seen in German Shepherd Dogs. Signs include pain, weakness, and rear limb muscle atrophy.<ref>{{cite web | title = Diseases of the Spinal Column and Cord: Degenerative Diseases| work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/100702.htm| accessdate = 2006-12-19 }}</ref> *[[Coonhound paralysis]] is a type of [[polyradiculoneuritis]] seen in [[Coonhound]]s. The cause has been related to a raccoon bite. Signs include rear leg weakness progressing rapidly to paralysis, and decreased reflexes.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Tick paralysis]]* is a disease in dogs caused by a [[neurotoxin]] found in the saliva of female ticks. ''[[Dermacentor]]'' species predominate as a cause in North America, while ''[[Ixodes]]'' mainly causes the disease in Australia. There is a gradual onset of signs, which include incoordination progressing to paralysis, changed voice, and difficulty eating.<ref name=Chrisman_2003/> *[[Dancing Dobermann disease]] is a type of [[myopathy]] that primarily affects the [[gastrocnemius muscle]] in [[Dobermann]]s. It usually starts between the ages of 6 to 7 months. One rear leg will flex while standing. Over the next few months it will begin to affect the other rear leg.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Granulomatous meningoencephalitis]] (GME) (including Pug Dog encephalitis and other noninfectious causes of meningoencephalitis) is an inflammatory disease of the central nervous system of dogs. It is a form of [[meningoencephalitis]]. The disease is more common in female toy dogs of young and middle age. *[[Facial nerve paralysis]]* is most commonly caused in dogs by trauma, [[otitis media]], or as an idiopathic condition. Signs include an inability to blink, drooping of the ear, and drooping of the lips on the affected side, although in chronic conditions [[fibrosis]] occurs and the ear and lips may appear to be in an abnormal position.<ref>{{cite web | title = Facial Paralysis: Introduction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/101100.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-19 }}</ref> *[[Laryngeal paralysis]] is unilateral or bilateral paralysis of the [[larynx]]. In dogs it can be congenital, seen in the [[Bouvier des Flandres]], [[Bull Terrier]], [[Dalmatian (dog)|Dalmatian]], [[Rottweiler]] and [[Huskie]]s, or an acquired, idiopathic disease, seen in older [[Labrador Retriever]]s, [[Golden Retriever]]s, [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]]s, and [[Irish Setter]]s. Signs include change in voice and difficulty breathing.<ref>{{cite web | last = Monnet | first = Eric | title = Laryngeal Paralysis | work = Proceedings of the 29th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2004 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2004&PID=8767&O=Generic | accessdate = 2006-12-19 }}</ref> *[[White dog shaker syndrome]] causes full body tremors in small, white dog breeds. It is most common in [[West Highland White Terrier]]s, [[Maltese (dog)|Maltese]], [[Bichon]]s, and [[Poodle]]s.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Wobbler disease]] (cervical instability) is a condition of the cervical vertebrae that causes an unsteady gait and weakness in dogs. *[[Cerebellar abiotrophy]] is caused by the death of [[Purkinje cell]]s in the [[cerebellum]]. It results in progressive [[ataxia]] beginning at a young age. It is most commonly seen in [[Kerry Blue Terrier]]s and [[Gordon Setter]]s.<ref name=Chrisman_2003/>
===Eyes=== *[[Eyelid]] diseases **[[Ectropion]] (eyelid folding outward) is a common condition in dogs, usually affecting the lower lid. Breeds associated with ectropion include the [[Cocker Spaniel]], the [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]], the [[Bloodhound]], and the [[Basset Hound]].<ref name=Gelatt_1999>{{cite book|author=Gelatt, Kirk N. (ed.)|title=Veterinary Ophthalmology|edition=3rd|publisher=Lippincott, Williams & Wilkins|year=1999|isbn=0-683-30076-8}}</ref> **[[Entropion]] (eyelid folding inward) is a common condition in dogs, especially the [[Chow Chow]], [[Shar Pei]], St. Bernard, and Cocker Spaniel. Upper lid entropion involves the eyelashes rubbing on the eye, but the lower lid usually has no eyelashes, so hair rubs on the eye. Surgical correction is used in more severe cases.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Distichia]] (including ectopic cilia) is an eyelash that arises from an abnormal spot on the eyelid. Distichiae usually cause no symptoms because the lashes are soft, but they can irritate the eye and cause tearing, squinting, inflammation, and [[Corneal ulcers in animals|corneal ulcer]]s.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Chalazion]]* is a [[granuloma]] that forms in the eyelid due to blocked secretions from the [[meibomian gland]]. Inflammation of the eyelid may result.<ref>{{cite web | last = Bjerk | first = Ellen | title = Ocular Disease of the Aging Dog | work = Proceedings of the 29th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2004 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2004&PID=8721&O=Generic | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> **[[Trichiasis]] in dogs is hair from the eyelid growing in the wrong direction and rubbing on the eye, causing irritation. It usually occurs at the lateral upper eyelid, especially in the English Cocker Spaniel.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Lens (anatomy)|Lens]] diseases **[[Cataract]]s* are an [[opacity (optics)|opacity]] in the [[lens (anatomy)|lens]] of the eye. Most cataracts in dogs are caused by a genetic predisposition, but [[Diabetes in dogs|diabetes mellitus]] is also a common cause.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.acvo.org/new/public/common_diseases/cataracts.shtml|title=Cataracts|publisher=American College of Veterinary Ophthalmologists|accessdate=17 August 2010}}</ref> The only effective treatment is surgical removal.<ref>{{cite web | title = Cataract Surgery in Dogs | work = Ophthalmology: Special Services, Technology & Information | publisher = NC State College of Veterinary Medicine | url = http://www.cvm.ncsu.edu/docs/ophthalservices.html | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> **[[Lens luxation]] is a displacement of the lens from its normal position. Terrier breeds are predisposed.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Nuclear sclerosis]] is a consistent finding in dogs greater than seven years old. Nuclear sclerosis appears as a bilateral bluish-grey haziness at the nucleus, or center of the lens,<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> and has little effect on vision.<ref name="Turner 2005">{{cite book|last1=Turner|first1=Sally|title=Veterinary ophthalmology: a manual for nurses and technicians|date=2005|publisher=Elsevier Butterworth Heinemann|location=Edinburgh|isbn=9780750688413|page=124|chapter=Nuclear sclerosis}}</ref> This is may be confused with [[cataract]]s.<ref name="Turner 2008">{{cite book|last1=Turner|first1=Sally M.|title=Small animal ophthalmology|date=2008|publisher=Elsevier Saunders|location=Edinburgh|isbn=9780702051050|page=6|chapter=Distant direct ophthalmoscopy}}</ref> *[[Retina]]l diseases <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Airedale Nigel with degenerative retina condition.jpg|thumb|An [[Airedale Terrier]] with a congenital retina condition and subsequent cataract formation, who was totally blind by the age of six years.]] --> **[[Progressive retinal atrophy]] (PRA) is a genetic disease of the retina that occurs bilaterally and is seen in certain breeds of dogs. It causes progressive vision loss culminating in blindness.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Retinal dysplasia]] is an eye disease affecting the retina. It is usually a nonprogressive disease and can be caused by viral infections, drugs, vitamin A deficiency, or genetics. Retinal dysplasia is characterized by folds or rosettes (round clumps) of the retinal tissue.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Sudden acquired retinal degeneration]] (SARD) is a disease in dogs causing sudden blindness. It can occur in any breed. The cause is unknown, but possibly involves either [[autoimmune disease]], a toxin, or [[Cushing's disease]]. Symptoms include sudden permanent blindness, dilated pupils, and loss of the [[pupillary light reflex]].<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Retinal detachment]]* is caused in dogs by genetic disorders such as [[retinal dysplasia]] or [[Collie eye anomaly]], trauma, inflammation or cancer. Reattachment may occur spontaneously or with medical or surgical therapy.<ref>{{cite web | title = Retinal Detachments | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/30116.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> *[[Cornea]]l diseases **[[Corneal dystrophies in dogs|Corneal dystrophy]] is a condition characterized by bilateral, noninflammatory opacity of the cornea. It appears as grayish white lines, circles, or clouding of the [[cornea]]. Corneal dystrophy can also have a crystalline appearance.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Corneal ulcers in animals|Corneal ulcer]], or ulcerative keratitis, is an inflammatory condition of the cornea involving loss of its outer layer. They are caused by trauma, detergent burns, and infections. Other eye conditions can cause corneal ulcers, such as [[entropion]], [[distichia]], [[Corneal dystrophies in dogs|corneal dystrophy]], and [[keratoconjunctivitis sicca]].<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Florida keratopathy]] an eye condition characterized by the presence of multiple spots within both corneas. In the United States, it is found most commonly in the southeastern part of the country.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> **[[Chronic superficial keratitis]] (pannus) is a form of superficial [[keratitis]], or inflammation of the cornea, found most commonly in [[German Shepherd]]s, [[Greyhound]]s, and [[Siberian Husky|Siberian Huskies]].<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Collie eye anomaly]] (CEA) is a congenital, inherited, bilateral eye disease of dogs involving the retina, choroid, and sclera. It can be a mild disease or cause blindness. It is known to occur in [[Smooth Collie|Smooth]] and [[Rough Collie]]s, [[Shetland Sheepdog]]s, [[Australian Shepherd]]s, [[Border Collie]]s, and [[Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever]]s.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Cherry eye]] is the term used to refer to canine [[nictitans gland]] prolapse, a common eye condition in various dog breeds where the gland of the [[third eyelid]] prolapses and becomes visible.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Canine glaucoma]] is an increase of pressure within the eye. It is a common condition in dogs. It can be caused by abnormal development of the drainage angle of the eye, [[lens luxation]], [[uveitis]], or cancer. Cocker Spaniels, [[Poodle]]s, and [[Basset Hound]]s are predisposed.<ref>{{cite web | title = Glaucoma | work = Ophthalmology: Special Services, Technology & Information | publisher = NC State College of Veterinary Medicine | url = http://www.cvm.ncsu.edu/docs/ophthalservices_glaucoma.html | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> *[[Ocular melanosis]] (OM) is a disease of the eye which in dogs is almost found exclusively in the [[Cairn Terrier]]. The disease is caused by an increase of melanocytes in the iris, sclera, and surrounding structures.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Keratoconjunctivitis sicca]] (dry eye) is common in dogs. Symptoms include eye redness, a yellow or greenish discharge, ulceration of the cornea, pigmented cornea, and blood vessels on the cornea.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome]] is a condition seen in dogs characterized by [[uveitis]] (inflammation of the inside of the eye), [[poliosis]] (whitening of hair), and [[vitiligo]] (loss of pigment in the skin).<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Conjunctivitis]]* is inflammation of the [[conjunctiva]]. In dogs it is most commonly caused by mechanical irritation (such as by [[entropion]], [[ectropion]], or [[trichiasis]]), allergies, and [[keratoconjunctivitis sicca]]. Any bacterial infection is usually secondary.<ref>{{cite web | last = Ofri | first = Ron | title = Clinical Approach to the Dog with Red Eye(s) | work = Proceedings of the 31st World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2006 | format = PDF | url = http://www.ivis.org/proceedings/wsava/2006/lecture21/Ofri1.pdf?LA=1 | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> *[[Eye proptosis]] is a condition resulting in forward displacement and entrapment of the eye from behind by the eyelids. It is a common result of head trauma in dogs. Most commonly it occurs in [[brachycephalic]] (short nosed) breeds.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Horner's syndrome]]* results from damage to the [[Sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic innervation]] of the eye. Signs include [[enophthalmos]] (sunken eye), [[miosis]] (small pupil), elevated [[third eyelid]], and [[ptosis (eyelid)|ptosis]] (drooping of the upper eyelid). Usually the syndrome in dogs is [[idiopathic]], but it can also be caused by trauma, tumors, or ear infections.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gustavson |first=Carrie |title=Horner's Syndrome Causes Pet's Droopy Eye |publisher=University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine |year=2000 |url=http://www.cvm.uiuc.edu/petcolumns/showarticle.cfm?id=23 |accessdate=2006-12-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207065303/http://www.cvm.uiuc.edu/petcolumns/showarticle.cfm?id=23 |archivedate=2006-12-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Optic neuritis]]* is inflammation of the optic nerves. In dogs this is most commonly caused by [[granulomatous meningoencephalitis]] or infection.<ref>{{cite web | title = Optic Neuritis | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/160610.htm&word=optic%2cneuritis | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> *[[Persistent pupillary membrane]] is a condition of the eye involving remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Uveitis]]* is inflammation within the eye. Anterior uveitis (inflammation of the [[iris (anatomy)|iris]] and [[ciliary body]]) is most common in dogs. The disease is usually immune-mediated in dogs, but may also be caused by trauma, cataracts, [[infectious canine hepatitis]], [[leptospirosis]], [[ehrlichiosis]], or systemic fungal infections.<ref>{{cite web | title = Anterior Uvea | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/30110.htm | accessdate = 2006-12-31 }}</ref> *[[Asteroid hyalosis]] is a degenerative condition of the eye involving small white opacities in the [[vitreous humor]]. The cause is unknown.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Synchysis scintillans]] is a degenerative condition of the eye resulting in liquified vitreous humor and the accumulation of cholesterol crystals within the vitreous.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Iris cyst]]s are small hollow structures either attached to the iris of the eye or floating free in the anterior chamber.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Imperforate lacrimal punctum]] is a congenital disorder of dogs involving the lack of an opening to the [[nasolacrimal duct]] (tear duct) in the [[conjunctiva]].<ref name=Gelatt_1999/> *[[Exophthalmos]] is a normal condition in [[brachycephalic]] (short nosed) dog breeds because of the shallow orbit. However, it can lead to [[keratitis]] secondary to exposure of the cornea.<ref name=Gelatt_1999/>
===Ears=== *[[Otitis externa in animals|Ear infection]]s are common in dogs, particularly breeds with hanging ears, such as [[Beagle]]s, and dogs with narrow ear canals, such as [[Cocker Spaniel]]s. Other predisposing factors include allergies, ear parasites, and [[hypothyroidism]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Otitis Externa: Introduction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/30900.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> *[[Deafness]]* in dogs can be either acquired or congenital. Predisposing factors for acquired deafness include chronic infection, use of certain drugs, and most commonly, age-related changes in the [[cochlea]]. Congenital deafness can be genetic, seen sometimes in dogs with [[merle (coat colour in dogs)|merle]] or white coats, or caused by [[in utero]] damage from infections or toxins.<ref>{{cite web | title = Deafness: Introduction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/30700.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> *[[Fly strike dermatitis]] occurs at the tip and folds of the ear in dogs. It is caused by bites of the [[stable fly]], ''Stomoxys calcitrans''.<ref>{{cite web | title = Diseases of the Pinna: Introduction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/30800.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref>
===Skin=== {{main|Dog skin disorders}} *[[allergy|Allergies]]* **[[Atopy]]* is an allergy to a substance with which the dog is not necessarily in direct contact. It is a [[type I hypersensitivity]] to a substance that is inhaled or absorbed through the skin. Up to 10 percent of dogs are affected.<ref>{{cite web | title = Allergic Inhalant Dermatitis: Introduction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/70300.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> It is common in dogs, especially seen in breeds such as [[Labrador Retriever]]s, [[Golden Retriever]]s, and [[Shih Tzu]]s. The most common symptom is itching. Affected areas include the underside, the face, the feet, and the ears.<ref>{{cite web | title = Canine Atopy | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/70301.htm&word=atopy | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> **[[Flea allergy dermatitis]] is the most common skin disease of dogs in the United States. It is caused by sensitivity to [[flea]] saliva.<ref>{{cite web | title = Fleas and Flea Allergy Dermatitis: Introduction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/71600.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> **[[Food allergy]]* in dogs is commonly manifested as itching, especially of the face, paws, and the underside. [[Allergy#Skin test|Skin testing]] has proved unreliable, and a trial of a hypoallergenic diet is usually used for diagnosis.<ref>{{cite web | last = Halliwell | first = Richard | title = Diagnosing, Treating and Preventing Food Allergy | work = Proceedings of the 27th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2002 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2002&PID=2545 | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> *[[Follicular dysplasia]] is a genetic disease of dogs causing alopecia, or hair loss. It is caused by hair follicles that are misfunctioning due to structural abnormality.<ref name="Griffin_2001"/> *[[Dermoid sinus]] a genetic, autosomal skin condition in dogs. It can appear as single or multiple lumps on the dorsal midline.<ref name=Griffin_2001/> [[File:Canine lick granuloma.jpg|right|thumb|[[Lick granuloma]] from excessive licking]] *[[Lick granuloma]] also known as acral lick dermatitis, is a skin disorder in dogs resulting from an urge to lick the lower portion of the leg. The lesion from the incessant licking is a thickened, firm, oval plaque.<ref name=Griffin_2001/> *[[Pemphigus]] is an uncommon [[autoimmune disease|autoimmune]] skin disease. The most common form in dogs is pemphigus foliaceus, which manifests as erosions and crusting of the skin and [[Mucocutaneous zone|mucocutaneous junction]]s. Pemphigus vulgaris is more rare and manifests as blister-like lesions in the mouth and at mucocutaneous junctions. [[Bullous pemphigoid]] is most commonly seen in [[Dobermann]]s and [[Collie]]s and appears as a scald-like lesion of the groin.<ref>{{cite web | title = Autoimmune Skin Disorders | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/60206.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-01 }}</ref> *[[Sebaceous adenitis in canines|Sebaceous adenitis]] is an uncommon [[autoimmune disease|autoimmune]] skin disease. Most commonly found in Akitas and Standard Poodles.<ref name=Linek>{{cite journal|last=Linek|first=Monika|title=Sebaceous adenitis in the dog|journal=Veterinary Focus|year=2008|volume=18|issue=1|pages=12–16|url=http://www.edliny.com/Encyclopedy/Veterinary%20Focus/181/2.pdf|accessdate=10 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322133027/http://www.edliny.com/Encyclopedy/Veterinary%20Focus/181/2.pdf|archivedate=22 March 2012|df=}}</ref> *[[Dermal fragility syndrome]], also known as [[Ehlers–Danlos syndrome|Ehlers–Danlos-like syndrome]], is a rare condition in dogs characterized by increased skin elasticity and poor wound healing. There appears to be a genetic basis for the disease.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Paciello | first = O. |author2=Lamagna, F. |author3=Lamagna, B. |author4=Papparella, S. | title = Ehlers-Danlos–Like Syndrome in 2 Dogs: Clinical, Histologic, and Ultrastructural Findings | journal = Veterinary Clinical Pathology | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–18 | year = 2003 | url = http://www.vetclinpathjournal.org/VOL32/VCP3201_13-18.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2007-01-01 | doi = 10.1111/j.1939-165X.2003.tb00306.x | pmid = 12655483 }}</ref> *[[Canine discoid lupus erythematosus|Discoid lupus erythematosus]] is an uncommon autoimmune disease of the skin in dogs. It does not progress to [[systemic lupus erythematosus]] in dogs. The most common initial symptom is scaling and loss of pigment on the nose.<ref name=Griffin_2001/> *[[Juvenile cellulitis]], also known as puppy strangles, is a disease that affects puppies. Its cause is unknown, but it is likely to have a hereditary component related to the immune system.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martens|first1=S.M.|title=Juvenile cellulitis in a 7-week-old golden retriever dog.|journal=The Canadian veterinary journal|date=February 2016|volume=57|issue=2|pages=202–3|pmid=26834274|pmc=4713003}}</ref>
===Endocrine diseases=== [[File:Anatomy and physiology of animals Main endocrine organs of the body.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The endocrine organs of the dog.]] *[[Diabetes in dogs|Diabetes mellitus]] in dogs is [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|type 1]], or insulin dependent diabetes: a lack of [[insulin]] production due to destruction of pancreatic [[beta cell]]s.<ref name="Type 1">{{Cite web|url =http://www.vetsulin.com/dog-owner/faq.aspx#11|title = Difference Between Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes|author = Vetsulin |publisher = Intervet|accessdate= 25 January 2011}}</ref><ref name = "Greco">{{Cite web|url= http://www.bd.com/us/diabetes/page.aspx?cat=7001&id=7404|author=Greco, Deborah|title= Ask Dr. Greco|publisher = BD Diabetes|accessdate = 25 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bettermedicine.intervetusa.com/june2006/managing_diabetes.html |title=Managing Diabetes-Better Medicine-E-Newsletter|date=June 2006|publisher=Intervet|accessdate=25 January 2011 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070208103248/http://bettermedicine.intervetusa.com/june2006/managing_diabetes.html |archivedate = 8 February 2007}}</ref> Current research indicates no evidence of [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|type 2]] diabetes in dogs.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=16151773|title=Canine diabetes mellitus: can old dogs teach us new tricks?|vauthors=Catchpole B, Ristic JM, Fleeman LM, Davison LJ |year=2005|publisher=Diabetologica|volume=48|issue=10|pages=1948–56|doi=10.1007/s00125-005-1921-1|journal=Diabetologia}}</ref> Among the causes of diabetes mellitus in dogs are [[autoimmune disease]] or severe [[Canine pancreatitis|pancreatitis]].<ref name=Fleeman>{{cite web|url=http://www.uq.edu.au/ccah/index.html?page=43608&pid=0|title=Canine and Feline Diabetes Mellitus: Nature or Nurture?|author=Rand, J., Fleeman, L.|year=2005|publisher=Centre for Companion Animal Health, School of Veterinary Science, The University of Queensland, Brisbane 4072, Australia|accessdate=25 January 2011|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Forms of diabetes which may not be permanent, depending on the amount of damage to the beta cells of the [[endocrine pancreas]],<ref name = "Herrtage">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2009&Category=8060&PID=53521&O=Generic |title=New Strategies in the Management of Canine Diabetes Mellitus|year=2009 |author=Herrtage, Michael|publisher=World Small Animal Veterinary Association (WSAVA)|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> are transient and secondary diabetes. Some causes of transient or secondary diabetes are [[Cushing's syndrome]], [[glucocorticoid]], [[progestin]] or other steroid use, and the hormones of pregnancy or heat. In these cases, correcting the primary medical issue may mean a return to non-diabetic status.<ref name=Fleeman/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chronolab.com/point-of-care/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=28&Itemid=45 |title=Hormones Which Raise or Lower Blood Glucose |publisher=Chronolab |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306052415/http://www.chronolab.com/point-of-care/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=28&Itemid=45 |archivedate=6 March 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://images1.wikia.nocookie.net/diabetesindogs/images/d/d5/Providing_care_veterinary_diabetics.pdf |title=Providing Care for Veterinary Diabetic Patients-Canine Diabetes |author=Davidson, Gigi |year=2000 |publisher=International Journal of Pharmaceutical Compounding |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329140550/http://images1.wikia.nocookie.net/diabetesindogs/images/d/d5/Providing_care_veterinary_diabetics.pdf |archivedate=29 March 2016 |df= }} ([[PDF]])</ref> Common signs include weight loss, increased [[polydipsia|drinking]] and [[polyuria|urination]], and [[cataract]]s. Treatment involves insulin replacement therapy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aahanet.org/PublicDocuments/AAHADiabetesGuidelines.pdf |title=Diabetes Management Guidelines for Dogs and Cats-page 7 |author=Ruchinsky, Renee |year=2010 |publisher=American Animal Hospital Association (AAHA |accessdate=25 January 2011 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305005745/http://www.aahanet.org/PublicDocuments/AAHADiabetesGuidelines.pdf |archivedate=5 March 2012 |df= }}([[PDF]])</ref> and use of a diet high in fiber and [[Carbohydrate#Nutrition|complex carbohydrate]]s.<ref>{{cite web | title = Diabetes Mellitus | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/40302.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-09 }}</ref> Oral diabetes medications cannot be used for dogs because none repair or surmount the permanent damage to the beta cells of the pancreas.<ref name = "Greco" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content.plx?P=A&S=0&C=0&A=627| title =Insulin Alternatives|author= Brooks, Wendy C.|publisher= Veterinary Partner|accessdate= 17 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bd.com/us/diabetes/page.aspx?cat=7001&id=7389|title=Diet for Diabetic Dogs, and Exercise Tips|author=BD Diabetes|publisher= BD Diabetes|accessdate=17 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://learn.genetics.utah.edu/content/begin/cells/badcom/index.html |title=When the Target Ignores the Signal |publisher=University of Utah Genetic Learning Center |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307071616/http://learn.genetics.utah.edu/content/begin/cells/badcom/index.html |archivedate=7 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> {{List entry too long|date=November 2018|reason=This disease in dogs has its own main article; use WP:SUMMARY style and compress more.}}
*[[Thyroid]] diseases, including: **[[Hyperthyroidism]]* is rare in dogs. The most common cause is thyroid carcinoma, a malignant tumor. Signs include weight loss, increased appetite, and enlargement of the thyroid gland.<ref>{{cite web | title = Hyperthyroidism | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/40604.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-09 }}</ref> **{{anchor|Hypothyroidism}}[[Hypothyroidism]] is the most common endocrine disease in dogs. It can be caused by autoimmune destruction (lymphocytic thyroiditis) or [[idiopathic]] atrophy of the thyroid gland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lbah.com/canine/hypot4.htm |title=Hypothyroidism|publisher=Long Beach Animal Hospital|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These two causes are responsible for over 95% of the hypothyroidism cases in dogs.<ref name=Leventa>{{cite web|url=http://www.leventa.com/Owner/about.asp |title=Leventa-Hypothyroidism Treatment|publisher=Intervet|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Signs include decreased appetite, weight gain, hair loss, dry skin/coat, skin that is cold to the touch, recurring skin infections, and lethargy. The dog may also seek out warm places to lie. The symptoms of hypothyroidism are shared with many other medical conditions; it may not be the first thought when a diagnosis is made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cliniciansbrief.com/cms/portals/_default/pdfs/capsules/Sept_04_Cap13.pdf |title=Hypothyroidism-Vague, Nonspecific, but Serious |year=2004 |publisher=North American Veterinary Conference |accessdate=25 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061101122058/http://www.cliniciansbrief.com/cms/portals/_default/pdfs/capsules/Sept_04_Cap13.pdf |archivedate=1 November 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}([[PDF]])</ref> Symptoms may not appear until 75% or more of the gland is non-functional. In less than 10% of hypothyroidism cases, the problem is not with the thyroid gland itself, but with the pituitary gland in the brain. The pituitary gland produces a thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arbl.cvmbs.colostate.edu/hbooks/pathphys/endocrine/hypopit/tsh.html |title=Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone|publisher=College of Veterinary Medicine-Colorado State|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> without this hormone to signal the thyroid gland to produce its thyroid hormone, the thyroid gland remains inactive.<ref name=Leventa/> Treatment is with oral thyroid hormone supplementation.<ref>{{cite web | last = Daminet | first = S. | title = Canine Hypothyroidism: What's New? | work = Proceedings of the 28th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2003 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2003&PID=6703&O=Generic | accessdate = 2007-01-09 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2010&Category=8391&PID=56114&O=Generic |title=Canine Hypothyroidism: Update on Diagnosis and Treatment|author= Daminet, Sylvie|year=2010|publisher=Proceedings of the 35th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Lack of enough [[Iodine deficiency|iodine]] in the diet can produce a form of hypothyroidism; without the proper amount of it, the thyroid gland fails to produce enough thyroid hormone.<ref name=Leventa/> [[Myxedema coma]] is a rare but serious aspect of the disease that is a medical emergency.<ref name=Durkan>{{cite web|url=http://veterinarycalendar.dvm360.com/avhc/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=586470&sk=&date=&pageID=3 |title=Endocrine Emergencies|author=Durkan, Samuel|date=January 2008|publisher= DVM 360|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> *[[Hypoadrenocorticism in dogs|Hypoadrenocorticism]], also known as Addison's disease, is a reduction of production of [[glucocorticoid]]s and [[mineralocorticoid]]s by the [[adrenal gland]]s. There is more familiarity with the glucocortcoids, such as [[cortisol]]; mineralocorticoids control the amount of [[Potassium in biology|potassium]], salt and water in the body.<ref name=PetEd>{{cite web|url=http://www.peteducation.com/article.cfm?cls=2&cat=1662&articleid=700 |title=Potassium Toxicity & Addison's Disease|publisher=Pet Education.com|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref name=NewHope>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhahonline.com/k9endocrinology.htm |title=Addison's Disease |publisher=New Hope Animal Hospital |accessdate=25 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113214741/http://www.nhahonline.com/k9endocrinology.htm |archivedate=13 November 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=endocrin.section.635|title= Endocrinology-an Integrated Approach-Aldosterone|author=Nussey, SS., Whitehead, SA.|publisher=National Institutes of Health (US)|year=2001|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> It is most commonly caused by destruction of adrenal tissue, probably by autoimmune disease. Signs include increased drinking and urination, vomiting, diarrhea, collapse, shivering and weight loss; at times neither the causes nor symptoms are especially specific.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vin.com/VINDBPub/SearchPB/Proceedings/PR05000/PR00127.htm |title=Chronic Diarrhea|author=Steiner, Jörg|year=2001|publisher=Proceedings of the 26th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref name=Addisons>{{cite web|url=http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content.plx?A=608|title=Addison's Disease-Hypoadrenocorticism |author=Brooks, Wendy C.|publisher=Veterinary Partner|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Because of this it is sometimes referred to as "the Great Mimic" or "the Great Imitator".<ref name=NewHope/><ref name=Stafford>{{cite web|url=http://images4.wikia.nocookie.net/diabetesindogs/images/6/6c/VT_20_09_490.pdf |title=The Great Mimic: Canine Addison's Disease |publisher=Veterinary Technician |date=September 1999 |author=Stafford, Debbie |accessdate=5 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328174119/http://images4.wikia.nocookie.net/diabetesindogs/images/6/6c/VT_20_09_490.pdf |archivedate=28 March 2016 |df= }} ([[PDF]] )</ref> It is possible not to see any symptoms of the disease until the adrenal cortex is 90% dysfunctional.<ref name=Southpaws>{{cite web|url=http://www.southpaws.com/topics-of-interest/addisons-disease/ |title=Addison's Disease |publisher=Southpaws Veterinary Center |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716112620/http://www.southpaws.com/topics-of-interest/addisons-disease/ |archivedate=July 16, 2011 }}</ref> Addison's can occur when regular steroid use is abruptly discontinued; during their use, the system the adrenal gland does not function at 100%. The system senses sufficient levels of these hormones in the body and does not signal for their production. Tapering the medication off gradually allows them to return to full production after discontinuation.<ref name=Addisons/><ref name=Southpaws/> About 35% of affected dogs are not diagnosed until they experience an [[Addisonian crisis]], which outwardly appears to be a "classic" shock and is a medical emergency.<ref name=Durkan/><ref name=Southpaws/> [[Hyperkalemia]]<ref name=PetEd/> can develop and cause severe [[bradycardia]]. Only typical Addison's patients have the risk of Addisonian crisis due to the lack of mineralocorticoids.<ref name=Addisons/> Treatment is with supplementation of mineralocorticoids in daily pills or a monthly injection. The atypical form and the form caused by abrupt withdrawal of steroids do not need mineralocorticoids.<ref name=Addisons/> Glucocorticoids are usually supplemented with oral [[prednisone]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Hypoadrenocorticism | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/40204.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-09 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2009&Category=&PID=53636&O=Generic |title=Management of Hypoadrenocorticism|author=Church, David B.|publisher=Proceedings of the 34th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association|year=2009|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> {{List entry too long|date=November 2018|reason=This disease in dogs has its own main article; use WP:SUMMARY style and compress more.}}
*[[Cushing's syndrome]], also known as hyperadrenocorticism, is characterized by an increase in glucocorticoids secreted by the adrenal glands. About 85 percent of cases are caused by a tumor in the [[pituitary gland]], while 15 percent are caused by an adrenal tumor. The pituitary gland produces a hormone that signals the adrenal gland to produce cortisol; a tumor can cause it to produce the adrenal-stimulating hormone even when it is not needed.<ref name=Cushings>{{cite web|url=http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content.plx?P=A&C=&A=619&SourceID= |title=What Exactly is Cushings?|author=Brooks, Wendy C.|publisher=Veterinary Partner|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arbl.cvmbs.colostate.edu/hbooks/pathphys/endocrine/hypopit/acth.html |title=Adrenocorticotropic Hormone|publisher=School of Veterinary Medicine-Colorado State|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Signs include increased appetite, increased drinking and urination, a pot-bellied appearance, muscle weakness, and lethargy.<ref name=Cushings/> Cushing's can be caused by overuse of steroid medications; in some cases, stopping the medication is enough to solve the problem.<ref name=Cushings/> Diagnosis can be difficult as there are no tests with both high [[sensitivity (tests)|sensitivity]] and [[specificity (tests)|specificity]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2009&Category=8060&PID=53613&O=Generic |title=Advances in the Diagnosis and Management of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism|author=Di Marco, Viviani|publisher=Proceedings of the 34th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association|year=2009|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Treatments include [[mitotane]], [[trilostane]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.noahcompendium.co.uk/Dechra_Veterinary_Products/Vetoryl_ACY-reg_ADs-_10_mg_Hard_Capsules_for_Dogs/-36949.html|title=Vetoryl (Trilostane)|publisher=NOAH Compendium of Animal Health-National Office of Animal Health UK.|accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref><ref name=Dechra>{{cite web|url=http://www.dechra-us.com/files/dechra/Downloads/Pharma/Datasheets/Vetoryl_10_mg_Hard_Capsules_for_Dogs_16-12-10.pdf|title=Dechra US Datasheet-Vetoryl|publisher=Dechra US|accessdate=3 April 2011}} ([[PDF]])</ref> [[ketoconazole]], or [[selegiline]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.drugs.com/vet/anipryl-tablets.html|title=Anipryl consumer information|publisher=Drugs.com Vet|accessdate=3 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lloydinc.com/pdfs/Endocrinology/Vol14_issue3_2004.pdf|title=Selegiline Treatment of Canine Pituitary-Dependent Hyperadrenocorticism|vauthors=Braddock JA, Church DB, Robertson ID|year=2004|publisher=Australian Veterinary Journal|accessdate=8 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129015812/http://www.lloydinc.com/pdfs/Endocrinology/Vol14_issue3_2004.pdf|archivedate=29 November 2010|df=}} ([[PDF]])</ref> Surgery is used in some cases of adrenal tumors.<ref>{{cite web | title = Hyperadrenocorticism | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/40502.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-09 }}</ref> *[[Diabetes insipidus]]* in dogs can be central, caused by a lack of [[antidiuretic hormone]] (ADH), or nephrogenic, caused by a lack of response of the kidneys to ADH. Neither form is common. Central diabetes insipidus (CDI) is usually idiopathic, but can also be caused by head trauma<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=2925484&dopt=Abstract|title=Transient, Traumatically Induced, Central Diabetes Insipidus in a Dog|vauthors=Authement JM, Boudrieau RJ, Kaplan PM |year=1989|publisher=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association|accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref> or tumors of the brain. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) can be primary (hereditary) or secondary (caused by a variety of metabolic<ref name=Schwedes/> and renal diseases, including Cushing's syndrome and [[pyometra]]). Because the disease is characterized by an inability to concentrate urine, the most common sign is increased drinking and urinating.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1939-1676.2002.tb02379.x|title=Water Transport in the Kidney and Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus|author=Cohen, Michelle, Post, Gerald S.|year=2002|publisher=Journal of Veterinary Internal Medicine|journal=Journal of Veterinary Internal Medicine|volume=16|issue=5|pages=510–7|pmid=12322698}} ([[PDF]])</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2009&Category=8072&PID=53639&O=Generic|title=Logical Approach to Polyuria and Polydipsia|author=Church, David B.|year=2009|publisher=Proceedings of the 30th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association|accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref> Treatment of CDI is to use [[desmopressin]], a synthetic analog of ADH. Treatment of NDI is to treat the underlying cause, if any.<ref>{{cite web | last = Nelson | first = Richard W. | title = Polyuria, Polydipsia and Diabetes Insipidus | work = Proceedings of the 27th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2002 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2002&PID=2556 | accessdate = 2006-01-09 }}</ref> *[[Acromegaly]] (also known as hypersomatotropism) is a hormonal condition resulting from over-secretion of the growth hormone [[somatotropin]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arbl.cvmbs.colostate.edu/hbooks/pathphys/endocrine/hypopit/gh.html |title=Growth Hormone|publisher=School of Veterinary Medicine-Colorado State|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> from the [[pituitary gland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://images3.wikia.nocookie.net/diabetesindogs/images/a/ad/Pituitary_diseases_Molde.pdf|title=Pituitary Disorders|author=Herrtage, Michael E. |publisher=University of Cambridge|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> The hormone is responsible for growth from birth to adulthood. Normally in adulthood, the [[Epiphyseal plate|growth plates]] of the bones close and the secretion of the hormone slows considerably. Because the bone plates close when entering maturity, the continued growth of acromegaly is not of normal proportions.<ref name=Acromegaly>{{cite web|url=http://images1.wikia.nocookie.net/diabetesindogs/images/a/ad/Jun06_Acromegaly_NAVC_Clinicians_Brief.pdf|title=Acromegaly|date=June 2006|publisher=North American Veterinary Conference: Clinicians Brief|accessdate=25 January 2011}}([[PDF]])</ref> Most dogs with the disease are unspayed females, but the condition can come about with use of medications containing [[progesterone]].<ref name=Acromegaly/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vetsulin.com/PDF/20585.pdf |title=Progestrone Use and Growth Hormone Excess |publisher=Intervet |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227135318/http://www.vetsulin.com/PDF/20585.pdf |archivedate=27 February 2012 |df= }} ([[PDF]])</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?db=pubmed&cmd=Retrieve&dopt=AbstractPlus&list_uids=6227190&query_hl=1&itool=pubmed_DocSum |title=Progesterone-controlled Growth Hormone Overproduction and Naturally Occurring Canine Diabetes and Acromegaly|author=Eigenmann, JE, Eigenmann, RY, Rijnberk, A, van der Gaag, I, Zapf, J, Froesch, ER.|year=1983|publisher=Acta Endocrinologica|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|pmid=7440347 |title=Acromegaly associated with transient overproduction of growth hormone in a dog|author=Rijnberk, A, Eigenmann, JE, Belshaw, BE, Hampshire, J, Altszuler, N.|year=1980|publisher=Journal-American Veterinary Medical Association|volume=177|issue=6|pages=534–7|journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content.plx?P=A&S=0&C=0&A=504 |title=Explanation of Progesterone's Functions |author=Brooks, Wendy C. |publisher=Veterinary Partner |accessdate=25 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nDluY5kl?url=http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content.plx?P=A |archivedate=1 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Acromegaly patients often also have [[Diabetes in dogs|diabetes mellitus]].<ref name=Cook/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?db=pubmed&cmd=Retrieve&dopt=Abstract&list_uids=12914747&query_hl=3&itool=pubmed_DocSum |title=Similarities in Canine/Feline Endocrine Disorders to Human Endocrine Disorders|author=Rijnberk, A, Kooistra, HS, Mol, JA.|year=2003|publisher=Growth Hormone & IGF Research|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> There is a transient form of acromegaly which can affect females at the [[Canine reproduction#Female cycle|diestrus]] portion of the reproductive cycle.<ref name=Schwedes>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=pubmed&dopt=Abstract&list_uids=10476528&query_hl=1&itool=pubmed_docsum |title=Transient Diabetes Insipidus in a Dog With Acromegaly|author= Schwedes CS.|publisher=Journal of Small Animal Practice|year=1999|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> This condition is brought about by the mammary glands<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=12534096 |title=The mammary gland, an endocrine gland|author=Rijnberk A.|year=2002|publisher=Nederlands Tijdschrift voor Geneeskunde (PubMed Summary in English)|volume=146|issue=51|pages=2457–62|journal=Nederlands tijdschrift voor geneeskunde}}</ref> excreting excess growth hormone, which is triggered by progesterone from the ovaries. As with non-transient acromegaly, spaying is necessary.<ref name=Cook>{{cite web|url=http://veterinarymedicine.dvm360.com/vetmed/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=665659&sk=&date=&pageID=3 |title=Identifying the reasons behind difficult-to-control diabetes in dogs|date=1 April 2010|author=Cook, Audrey|publisher=DVM 360|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> The symptoms can include [[Gingival enlargement|overgrowth or enlargement of gums]] with wide spaces between teeth,<ref name=Acromegaly/> increased drinking, increased urination, thickening of the skin and skin folds, enlargement of the tongue and excessive panting.<ref name=Utrecht>{{cite web|url=http://igitur-archive.library.uu.nl/vet/2007-0302-210224/Acromegaly%20due%20to%20a%20somatroph%20adenoma%20in%20a%20dog-Fracassi,%20Gandini,%20Diana,%20Preziosi,%20Ingh,%20Famigli-Bergamini,%20Kooistra.pdf |title=Acromegaly Due to a Somatroph Adenoma in a Dog|author=F. Fracassi|publisher=Veterinary Clinics of North America|year=2005|accessdate=25 January 2011|display-authors=etal}}([[PDF]])</ref> Acromegaly is also possible from a [[Growth hormone#Problems caused when the body produces too much GH|somatotroph adenoma]].<ref name=Utrecht/> The hormone [[somatostatin]] can also be useful in treatment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arbl.cvmbs.colostate.edu/hbooks/pathphys/endocrine/otherendo/somatostatin.html |title=Introduction to Somatostatin|publisher=Colorado State School of Veterinary Medicine|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Since hypothyroidism is connected with the release of excess growth hormone, hypothyroidism can be mistaken for acromegaly.<ref name=Mimic>{{cite web|url=http://joe.endocrinology-journals.org/cgi/reprint/168/1/59.pdf |title=Primary Hypothyroidism in Dogs is Connected with Growth Hormone (GH) Release|author=Lee, W. M. |publisher=Utrecht University|year=2001|accessdate=25 January 2011|display-authors=etal}} ([[PDF]])</ref>
===Gastrointestinal diseases===
*[[Megaesophagus]] is a disease of the [[esophagus]] characterized by low motility and dilation. Most cases in adult dogs are [[idiopathic]]. It is the most common cause of [[Regurgitation (digestion)|regurgitation]] in dogs. Other causes of megaesophagus include [[myasthenia gravis]], [[lead poisoning]], and [[Addison's disease]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Washabau | first = Robert J. | title = Gastrointestinal Motility Disorders of Dogs and Cats | work = Proceedings of the 30th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2005 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2005&PID=10944&O=Generic | accessdate = 2007-01-14 }}</ref> *[[Gastric dilatation volvulus]], commonly known as bloat, is a serious condition in which the stomach swells with air (gastric dilatation), sometimes twisting on itself (volvulus). Deep-chested breeds are at a higher risk of bloating. Factors that predispose dogs to this condition are intestinal [[foreign body|foreign bodies]], intestinal cancer, [[intussusception (medical disorder)|intussusception]], and other intestinal diseases. It has a poor prognosis.<ref>{{cite journal|title=What's Your Diagnosis?|journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association|year=2004|volume=225|issue=3|pages=361–362|format=PDF|url=http://avmajournals.avma.org/doi/pdf/10.2460/javma.2004.225.361|accessdate=2007-01-14|doi=10.2460/javma.2004.225.361|author=Trostel, C. Todd|pmid=15328709|last2=Dhupa|first2=S}}</ref> *[[Foreign body]] is an object foreign to the body that becomes lodged in the gastrointestinal tract (or other part of the dog). Dogs are susceptible to gastrointestinal obstruction due to their ability to swallow relatively large objects and pass them through the esophagus. Foreign bodies most commonly become lodged in the stomach because of the inability to pass through the pyloric sphincter, and in the jejunum. *[[Anal fistula]]e*, known as perianal fistulae in dogs, are most common in German Shepherd Dogs. They are characterized by [[draining tract]]s in the skin around the anus. The cause is unknown. Surgical treatment is common, but recently use of [[cyclosporine]] in combination with [[ketoconazole]] has been shown to be effective.<ref>{{cite web | title = Perianal Fistula | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/20603.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-14 }}</ref> *[[Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency]] is the inability to properly digest food due to a lack of digestive enzymes made by the pancreas. This disease is found frequently in dogs.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Canine pancreatitis|Pancreatitis]]*, or inflammation of the [[pancreas]], is common in dogs. It is most commonly seen in middle-aged and older overweight dogs. [[Miniature Schnauzer]]s are predisposed. Contributing factors include [[Diabetes in dogs|diabetes]], [[hyperlipidemia]], obesity, and [[dietary indiscretion]]. Signs include vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, lethargy, and anorexia.<ref>{{cite web | last = Simpson | first = Kenneth W. | title = Update on Pancreatitis in Dogs | work = Proceedings of the 31st World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2006 | format=PDF | url = http://www.ivis.org/proceedings/wsava/2006/lecture12/Simpson1.pdf?LA=1 | accessdate = 2007-01-14 }}</ref> *[[Inflammatory bowel disease]] (IBD)* is a group of diseases in dogs that are [[idiopathic]] and characterized by the presence of inflammatory cell infiltrates in the stomach and/or intestinal walls. It is a common condition. Signs include vomiting, diarrhea, and weight loss. Treatment is with dietary modification and use of medications such as [[corticosteroid]]s, [[metronidazole]], [[sulfasalazine]], and [[azathioprine]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Inflammatory Bowel Disease | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/23312.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-14 }}</ref> *[[Bilious vomiting syndrome]] is vomiting in response to bile-induced inflammation of the stomach. Bile salts interfere with the gastric mucosal barrier, allowing acid to irritate the stomach lining and cause gastritis.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Westermarck, Elias |author2=Wiberg, Maria |title=Canine gastritis|journal=The Veterinary Clinics of North America|year=2003|volume=33|pages=978–979}}</ref> *[[Intussusception (medical disorder)|Intussusception]]* is characterized by telescoping of one part of the gastrointestinal tract into another part, forming an obstruction. It is most common in dogs six to eight months old. Surgery is necessary for treatment.<ref>{{cite web | title = Gastrointestinal Obstruction | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/23308.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-14 }}</ref> *[[Lymphangiectasia]] is an intestinal disease of dogs characterized by chronic diarrhea and loss of proteins such as [[serum albumin]] and [[globulin]]. It is considered to be a chronic form of [[protein-losing enteropathy]]. Breeds commonly affected include the [[Soft-Coated Wheaten Terrier]], [[Norwegian Lundehund]], [[Basenji]], and [[Yorkshire Terrier]].<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis]] is a disease of dogs characterized by sudden vomiting and bloody diarrhea. The symptoms are usually severe and can be fatal if not treated. It is most common in young adult dogs of any breed, but especially small dogs such as the [[Toy Poodle]] and [[Miniature Schnauzer]].<ref name=Ettinger_1995/>
===Urinary and reproductive systems=== *[[Kidney]] diseases **[[Fanconi syndrome]] is a type of [[renal tubule]] disease found in [[Basenji]]s. Findings include the inability to concentrate urine, and the presence of [[glucose]], [[protein]], and [[amino acid]]s in the urine.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> **[[Renal failure]] (kidney failure) * is common in dogs and may be found in acute or chronic forms. It is defined by a loss of function of about 75 percent of the filtration system of the kidney and characterized by [[azotemia]] and low [[specific gravity]] of the urine.<ref>{{cite web | title = Renal Dysfunction: Overview | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/130602.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> Acute renal failure can be caused by loss of blood supply, [[hypercalcemia]], or toxins such as [[ethylene glycol]] ([[antifreeze]]) or [[aminoglycoside]] [[antibiotic]]s<ref>{{cite web | title = Acute Kidney Disease | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/130604.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> (see: ''[[ethylene glycol poisoning]]''). Chronic renal failure can be [[congenital]] and/or inherited or caused by cancer, infection, [[hypertension]], [[glomerulonephritis]], [[amyloidosis]], progressive interstitial [[fibrosis]], or any of the causes of acute renal failure.<ref>{{cite web | title = Chronic Kidney Disease | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/130603.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> **[[Glomerulonephritis]]* is the presence of [[immune complex]]es in the [[glomerulus]], resulting in leakage of protein into the urine. It can be caused by cancer, [[heartworm]] disease, [[pyometra]], [[rickettsia]]l infection, or [[systemic lupus erythematosus]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Glomerular Disease | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/130605.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> It can result in chronic kidney failure, [[hypoalbuminemia]], which can cause [[ascites]] and peripheral [[edema]], and [[nephrotic syndrome]], which can cause hypertension or [[hypercoagulability]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Grauer | first = Gregory F. | title = Diagnosis and Management of Canine Glomerular Disease | work = Proceedings of the 27th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2002 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2002&PID=2706 | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> **[[Familial renal disease in animals|Familial renal disease]] is an uncommon cause of renal failure (kidney failure) in young dogs. Most causes are breed-related (familial) and some are inherited. **[[Samoyed hereditary glomerulopathy]] (SHG) is an hereditary noninflammatory disease, of the [[renal]] [[glomeruli]] occurring in the Samoyed breed of dog. The disease has been shown to be a model for hereditary nephritis (HN) in humans<ref name=Jansen>{{cite journal |last=Jansen |first=Barbara |last2=Valii |first2=Victor E. O. |last3=Thorner |first3=Paul |last4=Baumal |first4=Reuben |last5=Lumsden |first5=John J. |title=Samoyed hereditary glomerulopathy: serial, clinical and laboratory (urine, serum biochemistry and hematology) studies|journal=Can. J. Vet. Res.|year=1987|volume=51|pages=387–393|pmc=1255344|pmid=3651895|issue=3}}</ref> *[[Urinary bladder]] diseases **[[Bladder stone (animal)|Bladder stone]]s or uroliths are common in dogs. The stones form in the urinary bladder in varying size and numbers secondary to infection, dietary influences, and genetics. Types of stones include [[struvite]], [[calcium oxalate]], [[uric acid|urate]], [[cystine]], [[calcium phosphate]], and [[silicate]]. Struvite and calcium oxalate stones are by far the most common.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> **[[Urinary tract infection]]*, specifically [[cystitis]] or bladder infection, is common in dogs and usually caused by [[bacteria]]. Signs include blood in the urine ([[hematuria]]), difficulty urinating ([[dysuria]]), and frequent urination ([[polyuria]]).<ref>{{cite web | title = Bacterial Cystitis | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/130502.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> The most common types of bacteria cultured from the urine of dogs with cystitis are ''[[E. coli]]'', ''[[Staphylococcus]]'' spp., ''[[Proteus mirabilis]]'', ''[[Streptococcus]]'' spp., ''[[Klebsiella pneumoniae]]'', ''[[Pseudomonas aeruginosa]]'', and ''[[Enterobacter]]'' spp.<ref>{{cite web | last = Senior | first = David | title = Urinary Tract Infection | work = Proceedings of the 31st World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2006 | format = PDF | url = http://www.ivis.org/proceedings/wsava/2006/lecture27/Senior1.pdf?LA=1 | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> **[[Urinary incontinence]]* is leakage of urine, usually due to incompetence of the [[Sphincter urethrae|urethral sphincter]] in adult dogs and [[ectopic ureter]] (a congenital condition in which the [[ureter]] enters the urinary tract posterior to the urethral sphincter) in puppies. In adult dogs it is most commonly seen in large spayed females. The lack of [[estrogen]]s in spayed dogs has been linked to development of incontinence. Replacement of estrogens, [[phenylpropanolamine]], and surgery have all been used for treatment.<ref name=Buffington>{{cite web | last = Holt | first = Peter E. | title = Urinary Incontinence in the Male and Female Dog or Does Sex Matter? | work = Proceedings of the 29th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2004 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2004&PID=8703&O=Generic | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> *Reproductive diseases **[[Prostatitis|Prostate disease]]* in dogs includes [[benign prostatic hyperplasia]] (BPH), prostatitis (infection of the prostate), cancer, and cysts and abscesses. BPH is the most common and is found in older intact (not neutered) dogs. Signs include blood in the urine and straining to urinate and defecate. [[Castration]] is the treatment of choice.<ref>{{cite web | title = Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/112402.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> Prostatis can be associated with BPH. Bacteria causing prostatitis include ''[[E. coli]]'', ''[[Staphylococcus]]'' spp., ''[[Streptococcus]]'' spp., and ''[[Mycoplasma]]'' spp.<ref>{{cite web | title = Prostatitis | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/112403.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> **[[Cryptorchidism]] is when one the testicles is retained in the abdomen or [[inguinal canal]] past a normal stage of development. It is a common occurrence in dogs and is thought to be a [[sex-limited]] [[recessive gene|autosomal recessive]] trait.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> **[[False pregnancy]]*, or pseudocyesis, is a common condition in female intact dogs. Signs include swelling of the mammary glands, lactation, not eating, and "mothering" small objects.<ref>{{cite web | title = False Pregnancy | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/112003.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> **[[Pyometra]] is an infection of the [[uterus]]. It is a common and potentially fatal condition in dogs. The main risk period for a female is for eight weeks after her peak standing heat (or [[estrus cycle]]) has ended.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Umbilical hernia]]* is a failure of the umbilical ring of the abdominal wall to close. They are very common and can be caused by genetics or by traction on the [[umbilical cord]] or by the cord being cut too close to the body. They are corrected by surgery.<ref>{{cite web | title = Hernias | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/20207.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> *[[Inguinal hernia]]* is a protrusion of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal. They are corrected through surgery.
==Cancers== *[[Canine transmissible venereal tumor]] is a tumor of the external genitalia (penis, vulva). It is spread by sexual contact and is more common in hot and humid climates.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Hemangiosarcoma]] is an aggressive tumor that most often affects the heart, the spleen, the skin and subcutaneous tissues, and the liver.<ref name=Morrison_1998>{{cite book|author=Morrison, Wallace B.|title=Cancer in Dogs and Cats|edition=1st|publisher=Williams and Wilkins|year=1998|isbn=0-683-06105-4}}</ref> *[[Osteosarcoma]] is an aggressive bone tumor that commonly spreads to the lungs. It is more common in large and giant breed dogs.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Histiocytoma (dog)|Histiocytoma]] is a benign skin tumor that is more frequent in young dogs (<4 years), and often regresses without treatment.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Malignant histiocytosis]] ([[histiocytic sarcoma]]) is an aggressive cancer found primarily in certain breeds including the [[Bernese Mountain Dog]], [[rottweiler]], [[golden retriever]] and [[flat coated retriever]]. It is characterized by infiltration of the joints, lungs, [[spleen]], [[lymph node]]s, and other organs by [[malignant]] [[histiocyte]]s.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *A [[mast cell tumor]] (mastocytoma) is a type of tumor normally found in the skin of dogs. It can also invade the [[subcutis]] and spread to the liver, spleen, or bone marrow.<ref name=Moore>{{cite web | last = Moore | first = Anthony S. | title = Cutaneous Mast Cell Tumors in Dogs | work = Proceedings of the 30th World Congress of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association | year = 2005 | url = http://www.vin.com/proceedings/Proceedings.plx?CID=WSAVA2005&PID=10953&O=Generic | accessdate = 2006-12-03 }}</ref> *[[Lymphoma in animals|Lymphoma]] (lymphosarcoma) is a malignant cancer that is classified by location, cell type, and histological grade. The most common form in dogs is multicentric, involving the lymph nodes.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Fibrosarcoma]] is a malignant tumor that most commonly occurs in the mouth in dogs, and less commonly in the skin, subcutis, and bones.<ref name=Ettinger_1995/> *[[Squamous cell carcinoma]]* is a malignant tumor in dogs that most commonly occurs in the oral cavity, including the tongue, tonsils, and [[gingiva]]. Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for 5 percent of skin tumors in dogs, and are the most common tumor of the toe. Dogs with unpigmented skin on the nose may develop this cancer from long-term sun exposure.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Perianal gland tumor]] (also called hepatoid tumor) is a type of tumor found near the anus in dogs that arises from specialized glandular tissue found in the perineum. They are most common in intact (not neutered) male dogs.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Anal sac adenocarcinoma]] is an uncommon and aggressive malignant tumor found in dogs that arises from the tissue of anal sac.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Melanoma]]s* account for four to six percent of skin tumors in dogs and are usually benign. They are the second most common tumor of the toe and are malignant in this location. Malignant melanoma is also a common oral tumor in dogs. Malignant tumors most commonly spread to the lymph nodes and lungs.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Leukemia]]s* are progressive proliferation of cancerous white blood cells within the bone marrow, resulting in destruction of the bone marrow and [[pancytopenia]] in many cases. Types of leukemia in dogs include [[acute lymphoblastic leukemia]], [[acute myelocytic leukemia]], [[acute monocytic leukemia]], [[acute myelomonocytic leukemia]], [[acute megakaryocytic leukemia]], [[chronic lymphocytic leukemia]], [[chronic myelogenous leukemia]], [[chronic basophilic leukemia]], and [[chronic eosinophilic leukemia]] (or [[hypereosinophilic syndrome]]).<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Plasmacytoma]]s* are common skin tumors in dogs that derive from [[B lymphocyte]]s. Most are benign. Tumors of B lymphocyte origin that affect the bone marrow and are diffuse throughout the body are malignant and are called [[multiple myeloma]]*.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Prostate cancer]]* is rare in dogs and occurs in both intact and neutered animals. It is malignant. The most common type is [[adenocarcinoma]]. Signs include blood in the urine and straining to urinate or defecate. It most commonly spreads to bone and the lungs.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Mammary tumor]]s in dogs are potentially benign or malignant. They occur most commonly in non-spayed females or female that were spayed later in life.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Insulinoma]]s* in dogs are [[insulin]] secreting tumors of the [[pancreas]]. The most common sign is [[hypoglycemia]]. They commonly [[metastasis|metastasize]] to the liver.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Oral cancer]]* includes tumors of the tongue, tonsils, [[gingiva]], and palate. The most common types are squamous cell carcinomas, malignant melanomas, and fibrosarcomas.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Eye cancer|Ocular tumor]]s* in dogs are found in the [[eyelid]], [[conjunctiva]], [[third eyelid]], [[cornea]], [[sclera]], [[iris (anatomy)|iris]], [[ciliary body]], [[retina]], [[choroid]], [[optic nerve]], and [[orbit (anatomy)|orbit]]. The most common types are [[Meibomian gland adenoma]] (eyelid), [[papilloma]] (eyelid), melanoma (eyelid, conjunctiva, sclera, iris, ciliary body, choroid), squamous cell carcinoma (conjunctiva), [[adenoma]] (ciliary body), [[adenocarcinoma]] (ciliary body), lymphoma (retina, choroid, ciliary body), [[medulloepithelioma]] (retina, choroid), [[ganglioglioma]] (retina, choroid), osteosarcoma (orbit), mast cell tumor (orbit), and [[optic nerve sheath meningioma]].<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Nasal cancer]] makes up one to two percent of all types of tumors in dogs. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type, followed by sarcomas such as fiborsarcoma and [[chondrosarcoma]]. Signs include sneezing and bloody nasal discharge.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Thyroid cancer]]* is rare and usually nonproductive in dogs (unlike in cats, in which it causes [[hyperthyroidism]]). One-third of thyroid tumors are small benign adenomas; the rest are malignant carcinomas, usually large and invasive.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Gastrointestinal cancer]]* is uncommon in dogs. The most common type is lymphoma. Nonlymphomatous esophageal cancer is especially rare, the most common types being squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, [[leiomyosarcoma]], and [[osteogenic sarcoma]] associated with the parasite ''[[Spirocerca lupi]]''. Nonlymphomatous stomach cancer is usually an adenocarcinoma, and nonlymphomatous intestinal cancer is usually [[polyp (medicine)|polyp]]s, adenomas, adenocarcinomas, leiomyosarcomas, and leiomyomas.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Kidney cancer]]* is uncommon in dogs. The most common type is [[renal cell carcinoma]].<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Lung cancer]]* is usually the result of metastasis in dogs. Primary tumors are rare. The most common type is adenocarcinoma.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Heart tumor]]s* are rare in dogs. Types include hemangiosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and [[fibroma]].<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Testicular cancer|Testicular tumor]]s* are the most common tumor of the canine male reproductive tract. Tumor types include [[Sertoli cell tumor]], [[seminoma]], and [[interstitial cell tumor]]. None commonly metastasize.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Ovarian cancer]]* is uncommon in dogs, with the most common type being the [[granulosa cell tumor]]. This type of tumor can metastasize and can cause [[cystic endometrial hyperplasia]].<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Uterine cancer]]* is very rare in dogs. The most common type is benign leiomyoma.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Bladder cancer]]* is usually malignant in dogs. The most common type is [[transitional cell carcinoma]].<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Hepatocellular carcinoma|Liver cancer]]* is usually metastatic in dogs. Primary tumors are and include benign [[hepatocellular adenoma]] (hepatoma) and malignant hepatic [[carcinoid]]s.<ref name=Morrison_1998/> *[[Brain tumor]]s* can be either metastatic or primary in dogs. The incidence of primary tumors is 14.5 per 100,000 dogs at risk. Types include [[meningioma]], [[astrocytoma]], [[oligodendroglioma]], and [[undifferentiated sarcoma]].<ref name=Morrison_1998/>
==Behavioral== *[[Pica (disorder)|Pica]] is an [[appetite]] for, or the behavior of eating, non-nutritive substances (e.g., [[sand]], [[coal]], [[soil]], [[chalk]], [[paper]] etc.). Pica can be dangerous to dogs, with a risk from eating dirt near roads that existed prior to the phaseout of [[tetraethyllead]] in gasoline or prior to the cessation of the use of contaminated oil (either used, or containing toxic [[PCBs]]) to settle dust. In addition to poisoning, there is a risk of [[bowel obstruction|gastro-intestinal obstruction]] or tearing in the [[stomach]] or blockage of the [[esophagus]]. *Pica in dogs may be a sign of [[Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia|Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia]], especially when it involves eating substances such as tile [[grout]], [[concrete]] dust, and [[sand]]. Dogs exhibiting this form of pica should be tested for anemia with a [[Complete blood count]] including [[Hematocrit]] levels, or [[Packed cell volume]].<ref name="plunkett">{{cite book | last = Plunkett | first = Signe J. | year = 2000 | title = Emergency Procedures for the Small Animal Veterinarian | publisher = Elsevier Health Sciences | isbn = 0-7020-2487-2 | page = 11}}</ref><ref name="feldman">{{cite book | last = Feldman | first = Bernard F. |author2=Joseph G. Zinkl |author3=Nemi Chand Jain |author4=Oscar William Schalm | year = 2000 | title = Schalm's Veterinary Hematology | publisher = Blackwell Publishing| isbn = 0-683-30692-8 | page = 506}}</ref> *[[Coprophagia]] is the ingestion by a dog of [[feces]], either its own or those of another dog or animal. It can be caused by medical conditions such as [[exocrine pancreatic insufficiency]], overfeeding, or [[malabsorption]]. It can also be a behavioral problem characterized by [[attention-seeking]], [[reinforcement]], or as a learned behavior. Numerous health problems can arise from this activity, including internal parasites or infection with ''[[canine parvovirus]]'' or [[toxoplasmosis]]. Treatment includes behavioral modification therapy or altering the feces to affect its taste.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hofmeister |first=Erik |author2=Cumming, Melinda |author3=Dhein, Cheryl |title=Owner Documentation of Coprophagia in the Canine |work=Information for Pet Owners |publisher=Washington State University College of Veterinary Medicine |year=1998 |url=http://www.vetmed.wsu.edu/pets/_archive/study.htm |accessdate=2007-01-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070106004711/http://www.vetmed.wsu.edu/pets/_archive/study.htm |archivedate=2007-01-06 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Environmental== *Sensitivity to [[Veterinary anesthesia|anaesthesia]] can occur in any breed, but [[sighthound]]s have been the breeds most documented to have anesthetic concerns. Sighthounds are known to have prolonged recovery times from ultra short-acting [[thiobarbiturate]]s such as [[thiopental]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Keegan | first = Robert D. | title = Your Pet is Going to be Anesthetized... | work = Pet Health Topics | publisher = Washington State University College of Veterinary Medicine | year = 2006 | url = http://www.vetmed.wsu.edu/ClientED/anesthesia.asp | accessdate = 2007-01-07}}</ref> *[[Dog heat stroke|Heat stroke]] can occur in dogs, especially in flat-faced breeds such as the [[Bulldog]] or in giant breeds. Breed, lack of water, exercise, and high ambient temperature predispose dogs to heat stroke. Signs include vomiting, diarrhea, collapse, difficulty breathing, and body temperature approaching 42 °C to 43 °C. Treatment includes cooling the dogs with wet towels and fans, [[intravenous therapy|intravenous fluid therapy]], and other supportive care.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Bosak | first = Jackie K. | title = Heat stroke in a Great Pyrenees dog | journal = Canadian Veterinary Journal | volume = 45 | issue = 6 | pages = 513–515|date=June 2004 |pmc=548637 | pmid = 15283523 }}</ref> If a dog's temperature begin to drop to around 40 °C, stop the cooling process. Once a dog’s body begins to cool, it can drop quickly and getting them too cool can create different problems. Allow the dog only a couple of laps of water until their temperature begins to drop to a more normal level. Do not allow a dog to gulp large quantities of water. If a dog is panting excessively and then drinks a lot of water, he will swallow large amounts of air with the water and this can cause an equally life-threatening case of [[gastric dilatation volvulus]] (bloat) in their stomach.<ref>[http://dogclassonline.com/puppy-health/heat-stroke-in-dogs.html Heat Stroke in Dogs]</ref> *[[Foxtail (raceme)|Foxtail]]s and [[sandbur]]s can penetrate the lining of the mouth or skin and migrate, causing abscesses and draining tracts.<ref>{{cite web | last = Knight | first = A. P. |author2=Walter, R. G. | title = Plants Affecting the Digestive System | work = A Guide to Plant Poisoning of Animals in North America | publisher = International Veterinary Information Service | year = 2003 | url = http://www.ivis.org/special_books/Knight/chap3/chapter_frm.asp?LA=1 | accessdate = 2007-01-07 }}</ref>
==Poisons and overdoses== *[[Acetaminophen]] (paracetamol, Tylenol) can cause liver damage in dogs. The toxic dose is 150 mg/kg.<ref name=Wingfield>{{cite book|author=Wingfield, Wayne E.|title=Veterinary Emergency Medicine Secrets|year=1997|editor=Hanley & Belfus, Inc.|isbn=1-56053-215-7|publisher=Hanley & Belfus|location=Philadelphia}}</ref> *[[Ibuprofen]] ([[Advil]])* can cause gastrointestinal irritation, stomach ulcers, and kidney damage in dogs.<ref name=Merck1>{{cite web | title = Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAID) | work = The Merck Veterinary Manual | year = 2006 | url = http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/214009.htm | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> *[[Naproxen]] (Aleve)* has a long [[Biological half-life|half-life]] in dogs and can cause gastrointestinal irritation, anemia, [[melena]] (digested blood in feces), and vomiting.<ref name=Merck1/> *[[Ethylene glycol|Antifreeze]]* is very dangerous to dogs and causes central nervous system depression and [[acute renal failure]]. Treatment needs to be within eight hours of ingestion to be successful.<ref name=Wingfield/> See [[Ethylene glycol poisoning]]. *[[Rat poison|Mouse and rat poison]]* ingestion is common in dogs.
